intro: Roeperia cleomoides, commonly known as the desert morning glory, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that open in the morning. The plant has hairy, ribbed stems and heart-shaped leaves that are adapted to conserve water in harsh environments. Its flowers are typically pale blue or violet, with five petals and a distinctive spur at the base. Roeperia cleomoides is often found in rocky soils and thrives in full sun, making it a hardy species well-suited to desert conditions.
